page.title: 06FARMING IN HEMEL HEMPSTEAD
page.content: The first{farmers}in Hemel Hempstead were Saxons who settled in the area in the 8th century. They chose Gadebridge because of the{water {supply}(the River Gade). St.Agnells Farm and Woodhall Farm have now been built on, but the following{farms still function in or near the area:- Eastbrook Hay, Lovetts End, Woodend and Wood Farm. The{land}consists of approx. 30cm topsoil, 2m clay and flint and at least 70m chalk.{Crops}grown include wheat, rape, kale, barley, beans, hay and lucerne. Potatoes are not grown as the ground is too stony. A few farm animals are also kept.{ { Drainage}in the area is good and flooding is rare. Eastbrook Hay Farm has its own underground water tanks holding 40 or 50 thousand litres.
